ranked_diseases.explanation: Mowat-Wilson Syndrome features intellectual disability, global developmental delay, thin corpus callosum, seizures, and specific facial features which align with the phenotypes presented in the patient. Obesity and short stature can also be seen in some cases.

This condition presents with global developmental delay, intellectual disability, seizures, and cerebral atrophy. Although obesity is less common, a wide spectrum of phenotypic variability is observed in Zellweger Syndrome.

Patients with Pitt-Hopkins Syndrome exhibit intellectual disability, developmental delays, and distinctive facial features which match some facial phenotypes of the patient. Seizures and cerebral abnormalities are also common.

Linked to X-linked hydrocephalus with thin corpus callosum and intellectual disability, this disorder can explain several neurological and developmental issues. Spastic diplegia may also occur in L1CAM-related disorders.
